column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	79	As Mr. Sheridan indicated

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	95	We have to think about the regime as having two instruments. The first is the loan-to-income ratio

column3: the loan limit is quite restrictive. For example

column1: #KieranODonnell	unknown-#KieranODonnell-party	unknown-#KieranODonnell-dob	unknown-#KieranODonnell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	96	Surely that would have been a reasonable proposition.
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	97	No
column2: and I will explain why not. There are two reasons. First
column3: when we see a rise in house prices

The figure was 18% for second-time buyers and 30% for buy-to-let mortgages. That is a fairly severe set of deposit requirements. The second point is more empirical. column5: only 11%
column6: approximately
column7: of first-time buyers were actually being caught by that rule. People had more in deposits than was needed – we discussed this point earlier. column1: #KieranODonnell	unknown-#KieranODonnell-party	unknown-#KieranODonnell-dob	unknown-#KieranODonnell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	98	I am asking a question. We suddenly had a measure in place by the Central Bank. It was put in place by the predecessor of Mr. Lane. It was a €220
column2: 000 limit for first-time buyers with a 90% loan. It was draconian in nature and particularly impacted those in Dublin
column3: more so than those outside Dublin. Suddenly
column4: the Central Bank took away any limit. The Central Bank left the loan limit at 90%
column5: with exceptions for some people who could go to 95%. Not long ago during the Celtic tiger
column6: we were complaining that mortgages of 95% and upwards were fuelling the price of houses. I want to know why the Central Bank took away the limit completely. Let us consider the first three months of this year. House prices went up by 4.3% approximately. The Governor stated last November
column7: when the Central Bank took away the limit
column8: that if there was a material change then the bank would make changes to the rules. Now
column9: the Governor is saying that the bank will look at it every November. November is eight months away. That is too long. It seems strange that the Central Bank went from having a limit to no limit at all. Is that a contributory factor in the increase in the price of houses? What does the Governor regard as a material increase in the price of houses? At what point will the Governor seek to bring some sort of control over the increase in the price of houses? November is eight months away. If house prices continue to spiral at the rate they are going
column10: it will put the value of the average home beyond the ordinary person. I always look at it in simplistic terms. Can the average couple afford to buy a home? If they cannot afford to buy a home
column11: then we have a dysfunctional system. The Governor referred to stability. Stability is not a macro issue; it is about something else. We saw a couple on an RTE programme last night. The loan is in negative equity and is a millstone around their necks. They are renting elsewhere. They are not first-time buyers curtailed by Central Bank restrictions. However
column12: let us consider the first-time buyers who are renting
column13: who are in their 30s and approaching 40 years of age. Such people are wondering whether they will ever qualify for a mortgage or buy a family home. I am asking a question. By lifting that limit
column14: is it possible that the Central Bank may be contributing to depriving these people from buying homes that they can afford? At what point will the Governor consider that a material change in price has taken place
column15: considering we have seen a 4.3% increase in the first three months of this year? At what point will the Central Bank step in and make the changes to ensure that an ordinary person who is making a living in an ordinary job can afford to buy a first-time buyer home?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	99	Senator O'Donnell has raised several issues. This goes back to the interconnection between financial stability and consumer protection. As Senator O'Donnell has said
column2: these rules have a double effect. Partly
column3: they serve to protect the system in order that we avoid a crisis of the same type from recurring. Partly
column4: they are in place to protect households. That is definitely part of our intention. Credit rules are not about solving the affordability problem in this country. For people on typical incomes to be able to afford a reasonable home
column5: the answer is all about expanding housing supply. Senator O'Donnell pointed out the specific change in our rules that might affect a house costing €300
column7: 000. The change is rather small because it is only at the margin above €220
column8: 000 where the extra deposit was required. This is not a major change
column9: especially in the context of a large fraction of people in that neighbourhood securing exemptions from the old rule. The old rule was complicated and had a wide exemption. Now
column10: we have a new rule that is simpler. The borrowing limit is 90% but there are few exceptions. Only 5% of first-time buyers can get an exemption from that rule. Therefore
column11: it is not the case that it is a material change that is driving the housing market. It is a simplification. I repeat that the anchor of the system is a limit of three and a half times income. This means that when house prices go up
column12: only people on high incomes are affording houses. That is why all the measures being worked on to increase supply represent the key to that.

column1: #KieranODonnell	unknown-#KieranODonnell-party	unknown-#KieranODonnell-dob	unknown-#KieranODonnell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	100	Why are house prices going up?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	101	I will outline a number of reasons for Senator O'Donnell. One is that the economy is growing. Employment is growing quickly. More people are looking to buy homes. Of course
column2: with the dysfunctional rental market
column3: many people are looking at high rents and are concluding that even though houses are expensive
column4: buying is what they believe they should do. It is part and parcel of the wider housing supply issue. Of course
column5: it is still the case that we live in a low interest rate world. Certain people
column6: especially those who take out a long duration mortgage of 30 years or so
column7: are calculating that some of these levels are affordable. However
column8: this applies to a limited group. What we are seeing is that only people on decent incomes are able to buy houses. That is essentially why it is not part of the overall solution. What we need is affordable housing. That is the core focus.

column1: #KieranODonnell	unknown-#KieranODonnell-party	unknown-#KieranODonnell-dob	unknown-#KieranODonnell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	102	What do we do until such a time as supply catches up? column2: especially in a low interest rate world. For that to be the limit on a mortgage is a severe restriction. In a European context

column5: that house prices are going above what we think is a reasonable zone

column1: #KieranODonnell	unknown-#KieranODonnell-party	unknown-#KieranODonnell-dob	unknown-#KieranODonnell-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	120	I never said anything about month-by-month. Really
column2: the response I have gotten from the Governor is that he will be doing nothing between now and November. I ask him to pay careful heed because we got into this mess in the Celtic tiger period when the price of houses spiralled out of control and suddenly people were taking out loans
column3: which I know had much higher interest then
column4: which effectively put them in negative equity. The loan-to-income ratio is fine
column5: but if the price of houses increases at an exponential rate
column6: there is the risk that there will be people buying houses again who will find themselves in negative equity in a relatively short period of time.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	121	This is why it is impossible to have an exponential

column3: it is so tempting to be fearful whenever the price of houses goes up
column4: and to say it will trigger extrapolation and a self-sustaining spiral. This is why the loan-to-income ratio is fundamental. Incomes cannot spiral upwards
column5: therefore mortgage levels cannot spiral upwards in this context. That is why there is a limit. With the loan-to-value ratio and the deposit requirements
column6: again people's deposits cannot spiral upwards. They have to save those deposits
column7: so it is impossible to have that spiral in the same way. A degree of predictability is needed in our rules
column8: and this is why a once-a-year review is a good way to do it. Going back
column9: I have said that if we see a material change we will change the rules
column10: but on a once-a-year basis. Doing so more frequently than that is not a good idea.

column1: #MichaelWDArcy	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-party	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-dob	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	122	I welcome the Governor. May I make a suggestion? As costs are rising

I think that is the term he used. Those fundamentals need to be able to trigger something. We need to understand what would be triggered in respect of situations where the Governor may have to intervene more than once a year. I understand his thought process in respect of the market but
column4: equally
column5: if the fundamentals are moving at such a pace
column6: something else may be necessary. I suggest that he give some thought to how he explains the triggering of those fundamentals to us in order that we are able to have confidence that he is flexible enough to move in a period of high inflation in respect of house prices.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	123	Let me provide a bit more guidance. Essentially

column4: I think we could be whistling past the recessionary graveyard again. That is not something any of us want to happen. We do not want to see the people in our offices again who we have seen for the past six or eight years.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	125	Perhaps this might provide some reassurance. We have an additional tool called the countercyclical capital buffer which we look at every quarter - every three months. This is something that can move at a much higher frequency. Its role is to detect overheating of growth in credit growing. I think it is a very good idea. Under European law
column2: every European country has to make a new
column3: fresh assessment of whether credit in the economy is overheating every three months. That is the measure we can move more frequently. In the Irish economy
column4: I would agree with the idea that we need to be continually looking. There is a lot of European focus on the phrase "countercyclical capital buffer". We just released our current assessment a few days ago. We do assess.We are forced to assess and have a routine of doing so every three months. We have a tool for the quarter-by-quarter-type assessment.

#MichaelWDArcy	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-party	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-dob	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	141	Okay. #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	142	We operate under our legislative powers. column2: it is not an issue about the Governor writing a speech or a report stating that the Central Bank of Ireland is concerned. One needs tools. We are using two instruments: first
column3: a set of mortgage rules and second
column4: a capital buffer so that if we think the credit market is starting to overheat
column5: we can force the banks to hold more capital and therefore be able to absorb more losses. Now we have brought in these mortgage rules
column6: which I think are fairly severe in a European context but we are open to tightening them if we think it is needed. In regard to the capital buffer
column7: it is still the case that credit is shrinking on net but if we get to a situation where we see credit surging we can intervene. There are other tools available. column8: the reason that I took on this role is that I think it is fundamental. I would hope that somebody with my background in economics would be able to make the call when needed.

column2: I hope that more cases get finalised. Only when the bank feels ready to announce it has a policy for this large group of people will it ride out and announce its rewards. If people do not like what they are receiving

column4: it is taking time. One might imagine that any one complaint could be handled promptly. However
column5: when that complaint is folded into a very large examination
column6: it does lead to delay. It is frustrating but our intention is that this will conclude with all of these cases being dealt with. Moreover
column7: it does not mean waiting to the end. As a cohort is dealt with

That is the linchpin in terms of anchoring the system. There is a limit to how much credit can fuel the housing market when we have that restriction. Going above that
column4: we have three layers of deposits. It is appropriate that first-time buyers have a lower deposit requirement than second-time buyers. It is 10% for first-time buyers
column5: 20% for second-time buyers
column6: and 30% for buy-to-let properties. We must remember that in the mid-2000s
column7: much of it was buy-to-let properties coming in and competing with first-time buyers but when there is a 30% deposit requirement for buy to let
column8: that restricts that. There are many breaks in the system. We may have these temporary surges
column9: especially in an economy where employment is growing strongly
column10: wage increases are beginning to happen and so on.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	236	I thank the Governor and his staff for attending the committee today. On the tracker mortgage issue
column2: the Governor has been very clear that lenders have failed their customers. That is a very serious environment for the Central Bank to be operating in and it should take it at the most serious level. On that
column3: we said earlier that the reasons banks treated customers in this way are unknown. We still do not know whether it was for economic advantage or collusion. Padraic Kissane
column4: one of the witnesses who came before this committee
column5: was clear on the harrowing stories families are still living through as a result of this issue yet the consumer has no information on that and no voice in that regard. That is a huge concern because justice delayed is justice denied and many of these families are still living in an environment where they are not aware what is happening and feel powerless. We have a number of public interest directors in our banking system who one would imagine would be the voice of the consumer on these issues. However
column6: they have been silent regarding these cases
column7: which is very worrying. I have some questions for the Governor. I refer to the correspondence I get as a TD.If people tell me they are engaging with the financial institutions but are not getting any information and are being ignored
column8: is there anything - having regard to his earlier comments about how the banking system has failed its customers on this issue - the Governor's office can do to compel the banks to give their customers information on their files with respect to where their cases are at?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	237	I will respond to that question and I will ask Mr. Bernard Sheridan to respond to it in more detail. There is a multi-layered approach to trying to represent consumers. The motivating factor for many people in the Central Bank
column2: especially in our consumer protection work
column3: is to try to protect the consumer through the range of powers we have. There is also the ombudsman process. As Mr. Bernard Sheridan said earlier
column4: it is intended that the framework that each bank runs has a consumer voice. The Deputy might argue about how independent that process is if the bank is picking the framework. There will be a majority of independent voices in the appeals process. I can appreciate the frustration experienced by customers if they are not getting sufficient updates on their individual cases. That leads to considerable distress because of the sheer uncertainty about not knowing what will happen. The only thing I can say about that is that I hope month by month an increasing number of cases will be resolved. We are pushing banks to do this as quickly as is feasible. I will now ask Mr. Sheridan to respond.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	238	The Deputy has asked a good question. Quite a number of consumers have contacted us directly. We have engaged a good deal with Padraic Kissane and I acknowledge the work he has been doing on this issue. We have required lenders to put dedicated units in place to deal with customers who have queries. If the Deputy has information on the way particular lenders are treating their customers
column2: we are happy to follow up on that
column3: and we have done that in the past. We are in this phase that is live
column4: as such. Even though lenders might not be able to explain to their customers their individual positions
column5: they should be able to explain what is happening
column6: the timelines involved and when they can expect to hear back. We are pushing lenders to do that but we are happy to be given information if consumers are not getting that treatment.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	239	That is critical because much of the information I have received suggests that the banking institutions are not giving their customers that information and they feel powerless in this area. The Governor mentioned the team he has and that the scope of the investigation will be very wide
column2: which is important. We have reports both from witnesses and from those in the media of how some institutions have changed the language they use and how it is very interchangeable and complicated. Article 5 of the Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Directive 93/13/EEC states: In the case of contracts where all or certain terms offered to the consumer are in writing
column3: these terms must always be drafted in plain intelligible language. Where there is doubt in the meaning of a term
column4: the interpretation most favourable to the consumer shall prevail.Will the Central Bank's investigation be established in line with the provisions of that article?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	240	Yes. That captures it. That same philosophy pervades many of our codes. There is a whole range of different regulatory requirements which essentially boil down to what the Deputy has just said. I will ask Mr. Sheridan and Ms Rowland to respond on what happens when these codes are violated.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	241	The Deputy has made a good point. This essentially is the core of where we are at in the examination. It is up to the lenders to deliver on this now in terms of their approach to
column2: and interpretation of
column3: it. They have to take the interpretation from the point of view of what a consumer would reasonably understand rather than from a legal contractual perspective. We are in the middle of this process with lenders and it is true that none of them is taking that approach regarding their consumer focus
column4: but we still have to continue to challenge other lenders. The test will be the outcomes of this examination in terms of what they deliver
column5: but that is a key element of this examination. The Deputy has captured the key element of its scope.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	242	I agree with that point. The essence of the provision the Deputy cited is a civil law protection. It is not a financial services regulatory law protection. It is something that attaches and is afforded to everybody who has commercial dealings in this State as a consumer
column2: and he or she can go to the court and vindicate that right separately.We cannot chase down an enforcement case based on that provision but it makes perfect sense in Ireland
column3: if consumer protection is at the heart of what we do
column4: that we interpret our regulatory requirements in line with the law of the land and in line with consumer protection provisions in the wider corpus of law that protects consumers. It is our clear expectation that all lenders behave in a way that puts consumers' best interests at the heart of their behaviour and interpretation of such requirements. That attaches to the interpretation of contracts
column5: the transparency provisions in our codes and what we expect as users and enforcers of financial services.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	243	There are different channels by which a customer who has been damaged can pursue a remedy. One can imagine a customer raising the matter with the Ombudsman and trying to sue the lender and in other jurisdictions such a matter might be resolved primarily through a court case. I believe this will prove to be quite effective for the Central Bank as the regulator using our regulatory powers
column2: which are quite wide-ranging
column3: to essentially avoid having all of these individuals taking court cases
column4: which would be intimidating and costly for them. The Ombudsman framework can be effective. At this scale it is limited
column5: whereas we can deliver a lot more through this framework approach.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	244	Our aim was to offer a consumer-focused
column2: more user-friendly approach as an additional option. It is true that it is in a moral suasion space but when we were putting together the consumer redress and compensation scheme we made every conceivable effort as lawyers and regulators to put the consumer at the heart of it. Where it is capable of being used
column3: the money is received upfront and one keeps that money and can appeal the decision. If one does not like the answer one gets on appeal - it is not that we recommend this but these are the available options - in addition to that
column4: one can go to the Ombudsman or to court
column5: but it is preferable that matters are sorted quicker
column6: simpler and easier through the use of an effective redress and compensation option at first pass without having to use those additional protections
column7: but they are available if they are needed. It was seen as a complementary option. Our aim is for this to be sorted as quickly as possible.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	245	That captures where we are in this argument with regard to the banks. When Mr. Kissane and others appeared before the committee they expressed a view that the Central Bank is the appropriate forum as the guardian of our financial system and regulator to investigate these matters and to hold the banks to account. I advise the Governor's team that thousands of people are relying on this and they still have faith that the officials in the Central Bank will sort this out
column2: but the clock is ticking. I ask that they do not betray that faith but ensure they hold the banks to account and get redress for these families.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	246	Public service is at the heart of our mandate. We are here to serve the public interest. This is a heavy responsibility for Mr. Bernard Sheridan's staff
column2: who are at the front line in leading this
column3: but it is a motivating factor knowing that in the end this will deliver. Time passes and it is very unfortunate that this has happened
column4: but at this stage we are hopeful that a lot can be remedied.

column1: #JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	247	To follow on from Deputy Burke's point and Ms Rowland's reply about the bank dealing with a query at first hand
column2: the context she outlined is not happening in many cases. That is where lies the difficulty. As a result
column3: we have received volumes of correspondence from clients of banks that have been badly affected. I will deal with some of their cases. For example
column4: clients may have written to their banks about their pre-March 2006 tracker mortgage and have gone through the process with the bank only to find that it does not respond or pushes them from pillar to post
column5: often forcing them to get legal advice and legal services at a huge cost. Instead of dealing with the problem
column6: the bank pushes it out and tests the customer in how far he or she is prepared to go in pursuing the problem.I understand we cannot name individuals
column7: but in one case a client wrote to us anxious that this matter be raised with the witnesses. I refer to the position before 2006
column8: what they bought out of the promotion of the product itself and then the discovery that when they sought redress
column9: the bank simply pushed them around. From 2010 to date
column10: they have not received any approach from the bank that they consider to be constructive or helpful. In fact
column11: they have fought all the way and are now at the end of their tether. This kind of issue falls generally within the area of tracker mortgages but also brings in other matters the bank has ignored. How does the Central Bank enforce this? As Ms Rowland said
column12: it has an obligation to deal with this type of custom before it goes anywhere else and without putting the customer into bad health and arrears because of the associated cost.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	248	I will make a few points
column2: and then perhaps Mr. Sheridan and Ms Rowland can say more. I agree that the relationship between a bank and an individual customer is typically totally asymmetrical in terms of the balance of power and any legal process
column3: its associated costs and so on. This is why the idea is that much can be resolved through this examination process which bypasses the need for individuals to take legal actions. Importantly
column4: this examination goes back to the mid-2000s so it will cover pre-2006 trackers. Anything with the tracker flavour is covered. I ask my colleagues to give some extra analysis.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	249	Professor Lane is correct. Pre-2006 tracker mortgages are clearly part of the examination. The three strands to the examination concern contracts
column2: and that is from day one; transparency
column3: which applies to what people were told at the beginning
column4: during the process and now; and whether there were other influencing factors. All these elements will play a part in the assessment
column5: but the Chairman's point concerns the manner in which the client has been treated
column6: which to me-----

column1: #JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	250	I apologise for interrupting Mr. Sheridan. This is just an example of how people are being treated by a bank that is becoming more arrogant by the day
column2: and most banks are. I wish to put on the record that I see a significant difference between the manner in which banks previously treated their customers and the manner in which they are doing so now. This customer I referred to says there is absolutely nothing in the promotional material they have from 2005 to suggest that a customer might lose his or her tracker. In other words
column3: they have investigated the matter
column4: they have the evidence
column5: they have presented it to the bank and they have asked the bank in a reasonable way to consider the matter and not to push them any further. They have told the bank they are almost a beaten docket because of what it has done to them. However
column6: the bank refuses to deal with them. This has been going on in this case since 2010. The bank is destroying this person's life. How many more lives is it destroying and what action can the Central Bank take?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	251	In the context of the examination
column2: the priority of our work in considering what has been happening is to focus on the people who are in scope and who the lenders have said have not been impacted. They are the people in respect of whom we really need to be satisfied that this is true. The lenders are making assessments
column3: as in the case referred to by the Chairman
column4: that perhaps the lender has no case to answer. We have put in a framework and independent oversight to verify this. Our role is to assure this happens
column5: and we have employed and are employing additional resources and expertise to challenge the banks. Ultimately
column6: if we end up in a dispute
column7: we will use all our supervisory and enforcement powers to deliver for the customer.

column1: #JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	252	When the Central Bank gets a letter like this
column2: where does it go? What happens after it gets a letter of complaint from a couple in such a situation? What is the process after they outline to the Central Bank what the issues are?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	253	We will consider that in the context of our own investigation and our own examination to see what issues it raises for us in terms of that institution and how it is treating its customers. We will also escalate the issue to the institution to make sure it is properly addressed at the appropriate level.

#JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	254	This couple wrote to the Central Bank on 20 March 2017.The witness might check the correspondence because I believe the couple have been treated badly by the bank and they are desperately looking to the Central Bank for assistance. column2: they have what I would consider to be a fair case. In another letter
column3: the correspondent writes that Ulster Bank
column4: which gave us a commitment in December to write to all of its customers and deal with the issues
column5: did not do so. To say it to a customer is one thing
column6: but it is another for the bank's representatives to say in here
column7: to a committee of the Parliament
column8: that it would write to and explain the matter to customers
column9: and then not to do it. That means the bank ignored its customers. The customer is king and
column10: having been in business
column11: I know one cannot ignore customers but take on board their criticism and suggestions. In this case the bank did not even bother. The bank told us it would write to its customers but the person who wrote the letter I received has asked who protects the customer. This person does not know where to turn.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	255	We want the banks to be in touch with customers as soon as possible. Mr. Sheridan will outline the process.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	256	I will not comment on specific institutions. The framework basically sets out the priorities in identifying the impact to customers

column4: so maybe the person is not in a cohort that has already been contacted.

column1: #JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	257	This person has been in the system for 18 months

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	258	I understand that point of view but it is not the legal framework under which we operate. Unfortunately

column4: including where we had to request permission from individual institutions to do so. column1: #JohnMcGuinness	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-party	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-dob	unknown-#JohnMcGuinness-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-04-04 00:00:00	Banking Sector: Quarterly Engagement with Central Bank of Ireland	259	I am asking the Central Bank to use its powers to hold these institutions to account. column2: it is shocking that banks do not even reply to these people. The answer is
column3: of course

column7: which is fine
column8: but that it would contact the client in question. That is fair enough. Bank of Ireland gave one sentence in reply and said it could not talk to us. Earlier Deputy Burke spoke about Padraic Kissane. On 9 March
column9: Padraic Kissane said that the deception is continuing on such a scale that it is worse it is getting rather than better. We listened to him here. In terms of the cases that he outlined
column10: the Governor can quote us the letter of the law
column12: and the regulators and banks will do their business. The customers have been pushed so far from the centre of things that they do not understand the language that the bank is using against them
column13: which is a real problem. Nobody has spelled out to the customer in layman's language exactly what the criteria is in terms of the investigation
column14: how long they can expect to wait or given them a complete brief on where their case is and instead customers have had to fight all of the way. column7: made me feel like I am on trial. I cannot tell you how many times I have wondered what I did wrong and why I am in this position.
